{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3649681,"name":"Chris Bale","username":"cbale2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-09T17:34:13.891Z","cooked":"

I’m currently investigating a replacement for our teams lathe, and figured I’d ask the folks on CD if you all have any suggestions. I’ve seen a few threads on the topic already, but most seem a bit dated so I figured I’d check to see if anyone had any more recent information.

Our team currently has an older LittleMachineShop HiTorque 3595 8.5x20 Deluxe Bench Lathe:

We’ve had a number of issues with this lathe, first starting with the tail stock being totally out of whack, the “DROs” dying on us (this one uses the battery-powered DROs on the control wheels themselves), and recently I discovered this thing doesn’t hold a tolerance (or for that matter, even just a position) to save its life, and it will just randomly jump like >0.02" as you’re moving it (whether that’s the DRO skipping or the machine itself, I’m not sure). As a result, it’s been difficult to use the machine for anything short of low-tolerance hole boring.

So, I’m scoping out alternatives we could replace it with. Cost isn’t a huge issue, since it’s something we can fundraise for (as long as it’s nothing too crazy) and we’re not in a rush, but size and accuracy is. Ideally, we wouldn’t want anything much bigger or smaller than what we have now due to the limited shop space (and it’s not like we’re turning anything huge on it anyways). I would like to have something with a proper DRO on it (extra points if any dials are in English Imperial units instead of Metric too), and it would need to have a stand (or have one available for it at least, even if it’s not included).

Any suggestions, and experiences are appreciated.

And I think it matches all of your criteria

EDIT: Alternatively, there’s this small one available on Facebook Marketplace

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-06-09T18:14:15.487Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":374,"readers_count":373,"score":234.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":502973,"topic_slug":"suggestions-for-a-new-small-lathe","display_username":"Zachary","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.precisionmatthews.com/products/pm-1022v-pm-1030v","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"PM-1022V 10"x22" / PM-1030V 10"x30" Precision Lathes — Precision Matthews Machinery Co","clicks":70},{"url":"https://www.facebook.com/marketplace/item/1048605743265374/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Redirecting...","clicks":33}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":10}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53819,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"ban the rev 40a breaker"},"post_url":"/t/suggestions-for-a-new-small-lathe/502973/3","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":8},{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":10,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3649702,"name":"Steven Smith","username":"Steven_Smith","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/8e8cbc/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-09T18:13:10.002Z","cooked":"

Yea if I was buying today for myself or a team I’d probably be getting something like this

Precision Matthews Machinery Co

PM-1228VF-LB 12"x28" Precision Lathe

  PM-1228VF-LB Main Features D1-4 CAMLOCK SPINDLE MOUNT, with LARGE 1.5” Spindle Bore, Best in class for universal chuck mounting, and the ability to accept larger diameter work that can pass through the spindle for much easier setup NOW WITH...

Most of the work you’ll do in an FRC environment, you won’t need a ton of power/torque for, and in some ways having the machine a little underpowered makes the difference between a mistake being fatal versus a mistake being just an injury (IE, machine stalls vs. pulls you through it)

Large Bore is nice so you can take something like 1.25" stock through the spindle (not super long though without a spindle liner, but say 12-18" of material), and you can make a part, part it off, advance the material, make a part, part it off, etc. Definitely spring for the AXA style wedge tool post or get another vendor’s.

As reference, I have an 11x27 variable speed from PM from ~2016 I bought, and I’ve run bigger and smaller manual lathes, CNC lathes, etc. The one I bought for 3005 was a grizzly ~10x24 or so manual, and it was noticeably less “fun” to use than my home lathe, in terms of fit/finish, ability to change speeds (change gears vs. VFD drive), etc. As I recall I paid ~$1500-$2k for that one in ~2018-2019. I’ve run up to ~14x30-40’s in the 3-5HP range in a school setting, and while “nice”, they are no “nicer” than the PM in terms of fit/finish, and just add more horsepower/size/risk than I need for the size parts I make. I’ve also run down to the “micro sized” $500 lathes you see at harbor freight, etc… and I’d consider them “ok” for illustrating concepts or making small parts out of 1/2" aluminum/plastic, with minimal risk/cost, but quickly frustrating if you are trying to make actual parts to a real tolerance. A good machinist can make a lot with a poor tool, but you are working past/around the tool.

EDIT → One last thing to add, definitely get the DRO. I haven’t run it in a school environment on a lathe, but I have on a 3 axis mill. I learned without it, so it isn’t as huge benefit for me, HOWEVER, The ability for the CAD students to make a drawing, hand it it to the “machinist students”, and play “drive to the number”, really worked out well. On the 3 axis, we’d often have things like aluminum tubing and a series of holes, with one student calling out the dimension and the other driving to it. It really just seemed to help them translate between “the numbers on the machine” and “the numbers on the drawing” in a way that my brain did automatically, but theirs didn’t initially. It also helps grease the mental rails towards CNC as well.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-06-09T18:59:14.317Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":356,"readers_count":355,"score":226.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":502973,"topic_slug":"suggestions-for-a-new-small-lathe","display_username":"Steven Smith","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":4,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.precisionmatthews.com/collections/lathes/products/pm-1228vf-lb","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"PM-1228VF-LB 12"x28" Precision Lathe — Precision Matthews Machinery Co","clicks":75}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20818,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/suggestions-for-a-new-small-lathe/502973/4","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3649736,"name":"Matt Golman","username":"BordomBeThyName","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bordombethyname/{size}/147649_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-09T19:26:00.388Z","cooked":"

Echoing the above, Precision Matthews is my recommendation for almost any small mill or lathe. Find the largest one that you can fit/afford.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-06-09T19:26:00.388Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":253,"readers_count":252,"score":185.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":502973,"topic_slug":"suggestions-for-a-new-small-lathe","display_username":"Matt Golman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9246,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mechanical/Strategy Mentor | 1678"},"post_url":"/t/suggestions-for-a-new-small-lathe/502973/5","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3649799,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-09T21:27:06.472Z","cooked":"

Quality you say?

Sherline Products

Factory-Installed DRO Lathes Archives - Sherline Products

Sherline lathes can be retrofitted to include a digital readout. Lathes can also be ordered new with factory installed digital readouts. This not only saves you the installation time, it saves a little money too, as you don’t pay for any of the parts...

I will say though, these are probably not the best for FRC use due to the headstock bore… Unless you want to get REAL comfortable turning between centers.

They are really made for smaller work, turning stuff in the 1/4" range.

We have been quite happy with our g0602 lathe. That said it’s nothing fancy.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-06-09T21:38:39.634Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":198,"readers_count":197,"score":74.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":502973,"topic_slug":"suggestions-for-a-new-small-lathe","display_username":"Mike","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28768,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"620 Software Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/suggestions-for-a-new-small-lathe/502973/7","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3649828,"name":"Rich Jr","username":"rich.varone","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rich.varone/{size}/167373_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-09T22:36:43.775Z","cooked":"

So we have 3x PM-1130V 11"x30" Precision Lathe — Precision Matthews Machinery Co and we can’t recommend them enough. The only thing we’d go back and change is getting the factory installed DRO. We also got the 5C collet chucks which has helped reduce error with the kids not centering the piece properly.

If you don’t want to get a DRO, highly recommend one of these, it really helped the kids who struggle with the backlash in these types of machines Amazon.com

5C collet also lets you load up one of these to help make a lot of the same part https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0713MR2SY

image1202×777 126 KB

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-06-09T22:48:06.540Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":178,"readers_count":177,"score":80.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":502973,"topic_slug":"suggestions-for-a-new-small-lathe","display_username":"Zachary","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":6998,"username":"rich.varone","name":"Rich Jr","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rich.varone/{size}/167373_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53819,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"ban the rev 40a breaker"},"post_url":"/t/suggestions-for-a-new-small-lathe/502973/9","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3649926,"name":"","username":"AVHon","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/avhon/{size}/130071_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-10T02:24:02.228Z","cooked":"

A DRO is an absolute game-changer on a milling machine, but in my experience is much less essential on a lathe (especially if you don’t have a quick-change toolpost and toolholders for each of your tools).

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-06-10T02:24:02.228Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":160,"readers_count":159,"score":56.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":502973,"topic_slug":"suggestions-for-a-new-small-lathe","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":20818,"username":"Steven_Smith","name":"Steven Smith","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/8e8cbc/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":41730,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"engineering mentor FRC 3494 & FTC 11329"},"post_url":"/t/suggestions-for-a-new-small-lathe/502973/10","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3649929,"name":"Zachary","username":"Zatack7","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zatack7/{size}/175437_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-10T02:27:50.286Z","cooked":"

I would argue that for frc usage, having a quick change tool post and a DRO are extremely important, as they help with ease of use (and thus make training faster). Also, they just make everything faster and better.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-06-10T02:27:50.286Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":155,"readers_count":154,"score":80.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":502973,"topic_slug":"suggestions-for-a-new-small-lathe","display_username":"Zachary","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":41730,"username":"AVHon","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/avhon/{size}/130071_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53819,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"ban the rev 40a breaker"},"post_url":"/t/suggestions-for-a-new-small-lathe/502973/11","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3649930,"name":"","username":"AVHon","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/avhon/{size}/130071_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-10T02:29:45.522Z","cooked":"

Along the same line as the Sherline, Taig offers a high-quality, inexpensive 5C collet lathe with and without z-axis power feed. Plenty of through-bore capacity, and you don’t have a trio of chuck jaws whirling about. (If you need a chuck, you just hold it in a collet on an arbor.)

Team 3494 has one of these lathes with a discontinued ER40 collet chuck (0.78" through-bore, 1" maximum capacity) and a chinese brushless sewing machine motor. The Taig Micro II lathe has proven to be extremely capable – it’s definitely much stiffer than the 10"x30" taiwanese lathe we used to have, and the cross-slide measurements aren’t weird metric conversions. To get precise and repeatable lengths, we use the z-axis depth stop, a feeler gauge, gage blocks, and a dial indicator on a magnetic base. Every tool has its own toolpost, so changing tools is about as fast as a quick-change toolpost, although without the positional repeatability. We have the optional compound slide, and had one or two occasions to cut tapers with it in the last 3 years. We also have the headstock and tailstock risers, but have never needed them. We cut lots of threads with taps and dies. The lever tailstock provides good feedback, and rapid clearing of deep holes. As I said above, I’ve never found a DRO to be a real necessity with a lathe, and I think using a simple 2-axis machine is a good way for new students to gain basic skills and confidence before moving to the more complex Bridgeport-style mill, which is extremely well-complemented by a 2- or 3-axis DRO.

Before buying a new lathe, I suggest better understanding the problems with the current lathe. Is it actually broken / badly-made, or is it just needing some maintenance?

Some thoughts on the DRO gizmos showing that it doesn’t hold position:

  • Is this when the carriage/cross slide are unlocked, or locked?
  • Does a dial indicator show these same jumps, or only the DRO?
  • Are all of the gib screws as snug as they can be without dragging on the ways?
  • Are the gibs, ways, leadscrews, and rack clean and oiled?
  • Are the DRO scales fully secured?
  • Are the toolpost, compound slide angle, headstock, chuck, and chuck backing plate secure?
  • Are all of the tool heights on center?

The cheap little DRO gizmos are cheap-in-a-bad-way. (I “used” some once that had almost a second of lag before they’d update their reading!) If the biggest problem with yours is just the batteries dying, I’ve seen people hardwire them for power by soldering wires from a 3V power supply onto the battery tabs. If yours are so bad that they’re not worth looking at, you can also remove them. Then you could use the lathe manually without being distracted by wrong numbers, or you could install a proper DRO.

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-06-10T03:58:55.859Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":139,"readers_count":138,"score":62.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":502973,"topic_slug":"suggestions-for-a-new-small-lathe","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":3,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":41730,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"engineering mentor FRC 3494 & FTC 11329"},"post_url":"/t/suggestions-for-a-new-small-lathe/502973/13","reactions":[{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"thinking","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3649990,"name":"Chris Bale","username":"cbale2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-10T05:36:35.534Z","cooked":"
AVHon:
  • Is this when the carriage/cross slide are unlocked, or locked?

None of the axis’ have locks on them at all by design. The closest thing to a “lock” would be engaging the power feed.

AVHon:
  • Does a dial indicator show these same jumps, or only the DRO?

None of the knobs that have DROs on them have mechanical dial indicators. It’s either digital, or you’re working blind. The Z-axis is a mechanical dial-only, but the dial appears to be metric (or at least doesn’t follow imperial increments when measured; without metric calipers it’s hard to verify).

As for the jumps, you can actually feel it when turning the knob, it’s like you hit a spot of no resistance, the DRO will jump when this happens, but the tool itself will not.

AVHon:
  • Are all of the gib screws as snug as they can be without dragging on the ways?
  • Are the gibs, ways, leadscrews, and rack clean and oiled?

I haven’t personally used the machine that much, but the mentors on the team that do I would think are familiar enough with it to check those things periodically, but these issues have been fairly long term.

AVHon:
  • Are the DRO scales fully secured?

As far as I can tell, the DROs only read the rotation of the knobs they’re mounted to, there are no scales on the axis themselves. The DROs are cheap/fragile enough that we’re not confident if we were to take them apart to inspect the scales (if there are any), that we could get them back together again.

AVHon:
  • Are the toolpost, compound slide angle, headstock, chuck, and chuck backing plate secure?

Everything seems pretty secure with the exception of the tailstock which was garbage literally from day one. We got it replaced at one point which helped a bit, but our mentors that use the machine more regularly commented “it’s a bad design” so there’s only so much they can do with it. For most of what we use it for it’s been “good enough”.

AVHon:
  • Are all of the tool heights on center?

Not the last one I used, but I was aware of that going in (like I said, I don’t use the lathe regularly, so I didn’t really know the correct way to center the tool) and that wasn’t the primary issue. I basically referenced the tool off of a shaft that was already the size I wanted to zero everything, then I replaced the shaft with the larger one to be turned down and attempted to run the tool back to that same zero but the machine couldn’t even do that (it was like 0.15" over sized).

cbale2000:

Not the last one I used, but I was aware of that going in (like I said, I don’t use the lathe regularly, so I didn’t really know the correct way to center the tool) and that wasn’t the primary issue. I basically referenced the tool off of a shaft that was already the size I wanted to zero everything, then I replaced the shaft with the larger one to be turned down and attempted to run the tool back to that same zero but the machine couldn’t even do that (it was like 0.15" over sized).

I know it’s not your issue, but just in case you or anyone else is looking for how to do this, Blondihacks has a great lathe series with tricks, tips and knowledge:
